title: Hear Submissively to Change Old Perceptions | Sri Madhu Pandit Dasa | SB 3.22.10 | 07.08.2024
speaker: HG Madhu Pandit Dasa

segments.key_quote: Hearing from an authority is a better experience than gaining personal understanding.
segments.summary: This segment introduces the core principle that hearing from a spiritual authority provides a superior experience compared to relying solely on personal understanding.

segments.key_quote: Because if you happen to see Krishna, if you are not pure, you are not able to understand Krishna.
segments.summary: This segment elaborates on the principle by comparing hearing about Krishna from a pure source to seeing Krishna directly, emphasizing the importance of purity and the nature of spiritual sound.

segments.key_quote: So spiritual hearing means you have to remove the shutter of rational mind.
segments.summary: This segment discusses the power of the Hare Krishna mantra and the importance of submissive hearing, which involves removing the filters of the rational mind to allow for spiritual transformation.

segments.key_quote: Realization is when it goes into your subconscious.
segments.summary: This segment explores how to effectively read Prabhupada's books to allow the knowledge to penetrate the subconscious mind, leading to genuine realization and transformation.

segments.key_quote: It is a book of declaration.
segments.summary: This segment explains that the Bhagavad Gita is not a book of logical proof but a declaration of truth, and that faith is awakened through hearing from a spiritual authority.
This segment shares a personal story about reading the Bhagavad Gita and emphasizes the importance of building faith before engaging in analytical study.

This segment discusses how submissive hearing can lead to a shift in paradigms, which are the perspectives stored in our subconscious mind, and introduces the concept of OPSA (Objects, People, Situations, Actions) as the content of our minds.

segments.key_quote: The primary feeling that we all paste is priti and apriti.
segments.summary: This segment explains how our perceptions are pasted with feelings of like and dislike (priti and apriti), and how our free will influences these attachments and aversions, leading to iccha (desire) and dvesha (aversion).
This segment discusses how likes and dislikes are stored in the subconscious mind, leading to attachments, and how submissive hearing can transform these attachments.

segments.key_quote: You should sit here for paradigm shift
segments.summary: This segment emphasizes that attending Bhagavatam class should be for paradigm shift through submissive hearing, and that even the speaker can experience transformation while representing Prabhupada.

segments.key_quote: Please develop great faith in hearing.
segments.summary: This segment encourages developing faith in hearing and reading, especially the Hare Krishna mantra, and emphasizes the importance of having the proper situational perception and context when chanting the holy name.

segments.key_quote: It is the context that brings meaning to everything.
segments.summary: This segment explains that context is more important than the sense objects themselves, and that the context in which we perceive something determines its meaning and impact on us.

segments.key_quote: Managing context is you can manage your managing the sense object.
segments.summary: This segment continues to emphasize the importance of managing the context in our minds, as it is more effective than trying to directly control the senses, and highlights the role of proper association in creating pure contexts.

segments.key_quote: You should fear the context in your mind.
segments.summary: This segment advises to fear the context in our minds rather than the sense objects themselves, and reiterates that submissive hearing is the key to changing these contexts.

This segment clarifies that the subconscious holds the context, which is a complex cognitive network with emotions and connections, and uses the analogy of a crown and a diamond to illustrate how context affects perception.

This segment emphasizes the need for rules and regulations, sense control, and tapasya (austerity) to manage the old paradigms and prevent them from influencing our actions, especially in relation to the opposite sex.

segments.key_quote: We all have our own problems.
segments.summary: This segment reinforces the importance of hearing from authorities, maintaining the right context, and being selective about associations to avoid absorbing negative influences and unnecessary problems.
